instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Hello everyone,

Firstly sorry for my english, french guy inside.

I brought a macbook pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> logic board inside, wasn't powering on.
History is a day, nothing happened when opening the laptop, that's all.

Nothing special inside, no corrosion, no liquid damage, never opened, pretty good state.

First, with the logicboard alone on my desk, mesures are :
5v017 and 0.000 amp.
Finding a short on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL>, but not on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (0.540 on diode mode)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> present (5,1 volts) <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> around 4.1 volts. <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> around 2 volts.

To isolate the CC, removed L6995. 
Short was not before it, but after, on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL>. No short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (at this time). 
Removed all caps <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR>/5/7/8/<CAPACITOR>C6988</CAPACITOR>/9, but short still there.
Decided to remove <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>. Then no short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL> (happy) but now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted ! (around 0.002 on diode mode)e

Resoldering L6995, plug-in USB-C charger => 5v017 on charger, 0.00 amp, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_GH3_VR</SIGNAL> now present (3.42 Volts). 
Resoldering <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> (the real mistake?) but nothing else. No short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL> (Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> shows 3.42 volts) but sill present on pin 2. I suppose resistance can isolate a short, because nothing is connected to the ground.

Removing <CAPACITOR>C7080</CAPACITOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (the most easier before thinking at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) and... nothing more. I decided to leave the board beside.

This morning, i plug the charger to make new tests, and, without touching nothing since the last day, charge stays at 5v017 but amp drop from 0.3 to 1.8A ! Nasty smell around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>... touching in the zone and burning my finger on Cap <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>... Damned !

Charger pulling down to 0.6 amp and 4.7 volts on first usb-c port, stay around this values and, around 5v017 and 0,3 amp on other port...

So i decide to take the voltage of <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> => 5,17 volts !! how it's possible !

I decided to remove <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>, and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Unfortunatly there still a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, and now another on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XA</SIGNAL> and XB. 

So i remove the <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR> and 3001, one by one.

Short is gone on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XA</SIGNAL> and XB, so i suppose <CHIP>U3000</CHIP> & <CHIP>U3001</CHIP> chips are fines.

But short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is still there !

I remove <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> to be sure again, but no difference...

Also tested keyboard connector who looks perfect, nothing special.

However, values are below :

Resistance from pin 15 to ground => around 2,6 ohms
Resistance from pin 16 to ground => around 0,9 ohms (same as shorting my multimeter)
Resistance from <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> (pin 2) to ground => around 2,6 ohms

So Pins 15 & 16 aren't shorted together, connector seems fine.

A idea for the nexts steps (without more destruction?)

thanks a lot for your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Please don't write so much in a post.
Try to go in the repair process step by step.
This way you can save time, avoiding wrong steps.

You've created a big confusion with <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> short to ground.
How can you get short one side of 0 ohm resistor, but not on other pin???
Is 0 ohm value man, between its pins.
EXACTTLY same value to ground should be on its both pins; unless resistor is open/burnt!!!
Short to ground on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> will burn <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>, of course.

"So i decide to take the voltage of <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> => 5,17 volts !! how it's possible !"
What's strange there?
Don't make confusion between a power rail and its enable signal!

Post diode mode to ground on all LDO lines of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Thanks a lot, and sorry again for my mistakes.

So values requested are below (diode mode, red pin on ground)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 612
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 639
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 585
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 614

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 617
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 631
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 580
 <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 608

(please note as <CAPACITOR>C3000</CAPACITOR>/3100 and <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>/3001 are still unsoldered from the board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Which is actual resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Check it in ohm scale (not diode), on both pins of <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> (to ground).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> pin 1 : 163 Kohms
<RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> pin 2 : 2,4 ohms

(<RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is soldered to the board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
First, as already said, <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is burnt/open.
2 ohm is low enough to find the short using voltage injection method.
Do not solder new/good <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> until eliminate the short...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
If I understand right (sorry if I ask for details) next steps are :
- remove <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>
- inject voltage directly on <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> pin 2 (or any other <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> spot on the board)
- try to find shorted component on the board, with fingers or isopropyl.

Never done that, but understand how it work.  major question is : how many voltage and amp may I have to inject to find it ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Set amp limit to max.
Start injecting with 1V and increase if needed; no more than 4V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
So,

I injected from 1v to 3.3v at 5A limit. Board take 0.17A at 3.3v max.

Nothing warm.

Retry to mesure my resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> => now it's 127 ohms !
Diode mode => 127

The only thing i removed before injecting is <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
You should get 0.300 in diode mode approx; and much more in reverse way.
<RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is already open/burnt in your board; doesn't influence in any way.

Did you inject voltage in the side with short to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
In diode mode i got 0.127 (sorry i don't write 0.xxx, my multimeter doesn't show the 0.)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7080</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3001</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> are still unsoldered, i don't know if it affect the value.

In reverse (ohm's mode) i read around 126 ohms, not more.

Injection done directly on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> rail (in test point right of <RESISTOR>R5168</RESISTOR>), witch was in short before injection (around 2,6 ohms)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Reverse way means black probe at ground; still in diode mode.

Resolder all the components and put new/good <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> (0 ohm).
Then post again diode mode readings on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and all LDO lines of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Thanks for explanations.

Is there a way to find new smd resistors & capacitors equivalence for apple products? And how to find exact value? (Don't have a donor board and my <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is dead, new one is on the way)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
For resistors/caps, schematics show nominal value and package size; like 0201, 0402, 0603, etc.
For the caps you should pay atention to nominal voltage, apart of capacitance.
Then you can search in any other boards, not only Apple stuff.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Ok. So if i understand right, <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is a 0 ohm resistor (0 under the name on schematic seems to be the resistance in ohms) so, in this case , it's just like a strap ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Yeah, most likely a fuse, to protect <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Right! more easy to bypass.

So, i put back <CAPACITOR>C7080</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3001</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> and all caps <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR>/5/7/8/<CAPACITOR>C6988</CAPACITOR>/9.
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> isn't there.

Before strapping <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>, value for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL> (diode mode) => 0.767 and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> => 0.040

I've made a strap to replace <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> :

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_VR</SIGNAL> (diode mode) => 0.040
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (diode mode) => 0.040

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 0.542
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 0.635
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 0.581
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0.612

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 0.544
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 0.627
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 0.576
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0.609

Note : before resoldering <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>/3001 and <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>/3200 i've taken <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XA</SIGNAL> and XB, each around 0.560 in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
You still have a problem with <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail...
040 in diode mode could mean 50-80 in ohm scale.
Not too low to heat something with voltage injection.
You can try, in case some IC enters in thermal avalanche.
Using IR cam may help you to see small temp differences.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is actually around 40,5 ohms.
In reverse diode mode, around 0.036 (Note that the <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> strap have been removed to take these values)

Is it normal to have the same value in diode mode and ohms mode for this rail?

So, if i understand right, next step is to inject again directly on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> around 3.5 Volts at Max Amp and pray for a notable short somewhere, that's it?

It's really strange that a firstly massive short to ground (around 2,6 ohms) becomes a short not so significant, don't you think? i haven't changed anything on the board, nothing replaced, only removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to be sure...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
"Is it normal to have the same value in diode mode and ohms mode for this rail?"
Depends by multimeter used.

You may have a capacitor partially shorted; its "ohm" value changes after burnt some part of internal layer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: And what about removing all capacitors on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> rail? There is not so much on schematic… finding short with so less consumption may be little more difficult don’t you think? What’s the best way to investigate more by your opinion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Best way is trying injection method as described.
If doesn't help, you can think to remove components one by one.
You can also heat the chips connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>; in case of accumulated crap causing leakage.

Doing nothing and just asking what else to do, doesn't help...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
So,
I injected again on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
On 3v board takes 0.16A, with 3,9V (the max i put on it), 0,23A

I use a thermal sensor, and find that <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is warming a little more than the rest (around 35°C while rest of the board is around 22°C). I'm sure it's in this area, especially around this component.

But with schematic, and the fact that with <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>/3100 and <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>/1 removed short was still there, i'm a little bit confused...

Actual <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> diode mode value is 0.133

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Did you inspect with thermal imager on both sides of the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
I don't have a thermal imager, only a thermal sensor i can put directly on the board then read thermal value. Only area with a significant increment value is <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> chip. All around seems to be only thermal diffusion from this point (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is less hot than 3100). 
I haven't tested other side of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Be sure the heat doesn't come from the opposite side of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: You're right. At the opposite of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> components, heat is more present. Found what seems to be a burning point on a component witch doesn't exist on board schematic ! It's a PI(burn)USB32224BXEAE.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
That is the USB redriver chip; many times mentioned on the forum.
The board can work without it.
Maybe weird issues with USB devices connected may appear; you should replace it finally.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Right ! I've unsoldered it. Short is gone (around 0.413 in diode mode, more than 1000Kohms in ohms mode).

Waiting for a "new" <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and another PI3USB32 to test the board. 

A little question : My hot air station go to 450° Celsius max (842 °F), and it was a little bit long and difficult to unsolder <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and this chip.  Do you know the right temperature to remove properly and quickly chips on these types of motherboards ?

Thanks again for all the time you spend here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Practise on scrap boards.
Also remove CPU heatsink.
Play with air flow, nozzle diameter and distance to board.
Each hot air station has its settings...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Hello 2informaticos,

So i received and replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Plugged in and IT WORKS !!! 20v / 0,6 Amp at both USB-C ports !! so happy !

I received PI3USB32224BXEAE too (but firstly i just wanted to know if the board run fine without it)

So after that, i replaced PI3USB32224BXEAE and... stuck at 5,07 Volts / 0,00 amps on first USB-C port  !!! (witch match with <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> chip)
On the other port, board runs perfect (19,97 Volts / 0,58 Amps)

Removed PI3USB32224BXEAE to see if the prob is gone, but now board still stuck at 5V / 0 Amp on first USB-C port... so i resoldered another new PI3USB32224BXEAE, same thing ! (First Port stuck a 5V, other run fine)

Reading some values on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips (supposing are fine, worked well before adding PI3USB32224BXEAE)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 0.609
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 0.637
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 0.584
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0.614

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 0.617
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 0.631
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 0.581
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0.609

With Charger connected on faulty USB-C port => <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> : 0,13V (same value for <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>)

Thanks a lot for your help !

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Ok thanks. 
It's really strange that the board works well on this port 2 days ago, juste before i solder PI3USB32224BXEAE, and now this port looks killed don't you think ? 
A reflow on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is possible or it doesn't do nothing more ?

Taken voltages on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> to be sure : 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 3,31 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 1,81 Volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 1,80 Volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0,03 volts

Will see for a <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: The heat applied when you've changed USB redriver chip, affected something else on Q/<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply.
I made a mistake with board in computer, trying to see if everything was working fine (screen/battery etc)
Plugged on second port (linked to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>) everything was fine (charging-aht-screen…). Unfortunately, i have unplugged from this port and replugged on the other port. USBc-meter show me 20v and 0 amp and all the machine shutdown, unable to turn it on again.
Checking ldo on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, missing smc one (open line). Everything stuck at 5v on each port, 0,3 amp on bottom, 0,144 amp on top. No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> when plugged on usb linked to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, got it when plugged on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
So I decided to remove <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, and soldering another Cd3215c00 (from AliExpress)
with the first one soldered, missing all connections on the top left, like 1v8 ldo.
Replacing with the other I brought, all Ldo’s were fines, but missing some others lines. trying to plug on each port to see if it can communicate with the charger, got 5v17 on each port, 0 to 0.04 amp cycling on bottom and 0.00 amp on top.

will see for others supposed goods <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, and resolder it. Reading that <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is the master, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> the salve. So without fully fonctionning <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, board can’t turn on properly.

is there a special tips to not destroying this sensitives Chips when resoldering?
Thanks a lot again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Hello again !

So i received my "news" CD3215C00 chips. Soldering one of them on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and....it's definitively alive 19,94V and more than 1 Amp on each ports !!!

Installing macosx, everthing works fine excepted a strange thing :

When i'm connecting my usb-c cable on first port (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> linked) it work on both side of the connector. When i plug this cable on the other port (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked) it work only on one side of the cable, returning the cable doesn't do anything (no charging, nothing detected)...  Usb-c cables aren't supposed to be similar on each side? how can it be possible?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Check USB-C connector terminals for corrosion first.
Next, compare diode mode readings on CC1/2 lines with the other port.

USB data lines are referred with BOT (bottom) and TOP (top) in their name.
Compare similar TOP and BOT lines, in diode mode to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Ok thanks.
No corrosion at all.

<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> (Bottom-<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked one) : 0.745
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1_CONN</SIGNAL> : 0.868
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> (Top-<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked one) : 0.751
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2_CONN</SIGNAL> : 0.866
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> (Bottom-<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> linked one) : 0.749
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1_CONN</SIGNAL> : 0.860
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL> (Top-<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> linked one) : 0.763
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2_CONN</SIGNAL> : 0.881

Found that the faulty one is the Bottom port-<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked, the only one with a different value on one UsbC connector pin (see picture below)

I have a pin that's not Open Lined, but with 0.040 in diode mode. In this page ([URL]http://logi.wiki/index.php/USB-C_Pinout[/URL]), i suppose it's the D+

Also remembered a thing :
When i have plugged yesterday my charger+usb-c meter on the faulty usb-c port (before knowing it was partially ko) got 20v and 0.7 amp but i see a tiny flashlight and a "pop" sound near <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, on the left side of the chip (around <CAPACITOR>C3109</CAPACITOR>). It doesn't change anything on the Usb-c meter, and board continue to run fine. Maybe a blowing capacitor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Check the TVS protection diode on the corresponding line; is the first suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Ok. I made a mistake, CC1 lines are top, CC2 bottom (regarding to schematic) 
So supposed faulty line is <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_USB_TOP_P</SIGNAL>, witch is equal to <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_USB_DBG_TOP_P</SIGNAL>

On schematic, there is only one component on this line, <DIODE>D3312</DIODE>. This is that you call TVS diode? 

Only TVS Diodes called like this on schematic are <DIODE>D3308</DIODE>/<DIODE>D3309</DIODE>/<DIODE>D3408</DIODE>/<DIODE>D3409</DIODE>, that's why i ask this. (and all seems to be goods, diode mode done before on CC1/2 lines are fines)

To test <DIODE>D3312</DIODE>, i need to remove the shield covering all connector and <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Never done that before, so i want to be sure not doing a mistake again...

Lastly, can i remove <DIODE>D3312</DIODE>, checking diode mode, and if it's open line, plug directly my charger on this port? No major risk doing this?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
If there is pure short, you can use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V and increase bit a bit, if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: 0.042 on diode mode is a pure short to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: No, low chance to heat something...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Hum… i see.
So if I resume, it’s a data line partially shorted.
It Could be <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <DIODE>D3312</DIODE> or replaced redriver chip, nothing more on the line.

two options: continue investigating, or just use the machine like that.
Is there a risk to use it with this short? (I mean plug-in a device and burn it) 
And is there a configuration in thunderbolt 3 that use both side of connector at same time? (I suppose for high speed data/power or something that could be limitate the machine usage in time) or it’s just a side that doesn’t work and that’s all?

thank again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Only one side of USB-C port is used at a time.
You can test fi that low value disappears removing USB redriver chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Thanks for suggestion!
So i removed redriver chip, low value still here (little bit high but still there)

I decided to test the board without redriver, and all sides of all connectors works. So then i decided to solder a "new" Redriver chip (from my 5 units lot) with a different method (making solder bulb on the chip, not on the board) and slowly heating the board. Redriver is now soldered on the board, and all sides are working!

I try to remove maximum flux, but i don't have ultrasonic cleaner. My flux is this one : [URL]https://www.computer-systems.gr/en/content/product/cs-flux-10g[/URL]
Is there a risk to leave it on the board? 

I can't test thunderbolt link for the moment (only have charger usb-c interface) but will test it later.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Do not use ultrasonic cleaner to clean small areas with flux.
Use toothbrush and alcohol instead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: That's what i did (isopropyl+toothbrush), but still have sticky flux on the board, unable to remove it only with toothbrush and isopropyl. Don't want to use pcb cleaner, already have a bad experience with it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Leave it as is, don't risk to induce other damage on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Ok thanks.

So i tried the board on dual screen and usb-c dock.

On first usb-c connector (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> link) no screen detected, but all things connected in usb-c (ethernet / USB / charger) is ok, in both sides
On second usb-c connector (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> link) i have the output for the screen, and the video recopy is ok. But i have major detection problems with docks (ethernet is ok, but didn't charge a phone or other issues, in both sides)

In my system preferences, when a monitor is plugged even in first or second connector, nothing appears in the thunderbolt area (no connection detected) but it seems to works fine on the second connector...

Don't know if it's interesting to investigate more, but it's a little bit frustating....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
USB redriver chip should be involved on these symptoms.
May also have some broken trace on the Thunderbolt area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Should I remove the redriver chip and see if it run better without? This chip is my major problem on this board, and is involved in all my issues since the beginning…  assuming it’s not a Perfect way to leave the board without it, but with it it’s worse…

Thunderbolt area looks fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (2016 thunderbolt3) board doesn’t have this redriver (schematic is based on this board), why It’s necessary on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>? It’s seems to be closer the same board…

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
So i removed Usb redriver chip for the moment. 

Can <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> / 3200 be involved in my usb-c troubles ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips are connected to USB data lines...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
For sure. But each chip is for a single port, no communication between them for theses lines, right?
supposing I soldered a partially bad <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is still the original)  data line can make all my usb-c equipments to work but didn’t’ detect a monitor ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
HDMI output is managed by <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, which can be affected on some of its USB data lines.
If USB redriver chip was burnt, is because of overvoltage, usually from fake charger; sometimes even PCH dies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Ok thanks for all this explanations.

all i know it's it is an oem charger an cable, but cable was partially ruined (needed to flex it in many ways to have signal on the board, that was done by previous owner. Can Suppose a voltage dropped to data line inside the cable) Since the beginning of my revival experience, i use brand new cable and oem charger.

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> seems to output correctly on second port, but nothing on first.
Is there an way or an order to test <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and PCH properly? 

thanks again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
So I have unsoldered redriver chip from the board.
Symptoms are still the sames (working outpout monitor on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked usb-c port, nothing on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> linked, fully working usb détection, management and charging on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> linked port, only charging and Sometimes détection on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked port)

a way to investigate more?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Check the traces continuity on the bad port.
Also compare diode mode to ground readings between both ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
Suppose that i have already done that (tell me if it’s incorrect) when I found that d+ pin on bottom side of the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> linked usb-C port was at 0.042 in diode mode instead of O.L. on other ports.

anything else I can check? Maybe <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> involved in my issues?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
HDMI output is done through <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.
But normal USB activity should be same on both ports.
You may have damaged traces, possibly into internal copper layers.
Some protection diodes may have leakage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message: Ok. So I suppose next thing to do is remove massive shield upper <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> area and see if something is bad along j3300, like a protection diode or burn resistor right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
If you are lucky and is not a trace problem.
Maybe not worth the job if you get HDMI one port and good USB detection on other port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / No boot / <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> Short to ground
threads.message:
For sure. That’s why I ask for an evidence to test or doing.
My Major problem is outputting on dual screens, which is not possible actually.
With only 2 thunderbolts, and just one with video outpout, combinations are limited.
